content.description:
Start directly below the top of the right-leaning crack in the middle of Pusherman Wall. Climb straight up on jugs, passing just to the right of a small tree growing out of the crack.

 Note: despite the YDS rating from ages ago, this is really a boulder problem.
content.location: It is directly below the top of the right-leaning crack in the middle of Pusherman Wall. See the picture on the Pusherman Wall page.

content.description:
In the middle of Pusherman Wall, there's an 8-inch crack. To the left side of the crack is a triangular block about 10 feet high. Climb the block just left of the crack, straight up from the ground to the anchors. The top of the block is broad, and the climbing is easy from here. It's slightly more difficult below. 

  Boston Rocks 2nd edition is confusing (p. 102). The route is graded 5.3. There's no route description, just a drawing which shows the route going straight up the block. However, in reality, the bottom of the block is fairly blank, making it much harder than 5.3. Therefore, I assume it's fair to use the arête which makes up the left side of the large crack.
content.protection: A toprope. Bring long slings or static line; there are sturdy trees about 15-20 feet back from the top of the route.
content.location: The route goes up the triangular block to the left of the 8-inch crack which splits Pusherman Wall in half. Probably it's fair to use the arête which makes up the left side of that crack, otherwise the climb is not 5.3. The top of the block makes a nice sturdy ledge. From here on up it's very easy climbing. You can top out or lower down.

content.description: Climb straight up on good holds.
content.location: Start about 3 feet right of The Bone.

content.description:
Start 5 feet right of the offwidth crack at the base of the right-leaning crack. Climb straight up. The top is somewhat overgrown, traverse left or right to top out.

 Note: despite the YDS rating from ages ago, this is really a boulder problem.
content.location: It is in the middle of Pusherman Wall 5 feet right of Just Say No.

content.description:
Jump up to the big holds just right of the high point of the arching, horizontal crack, or climb up the blocky, angling crack on the right, then traverse back left. Move up from the horizontal crack using the flake holds above to a slab topout. 

  The traverse version is one of Hammond's best easy problems, in my opinion. 

Boston Rocks rates gives this an old school rating of 5.9-.
content.location: This is on the mostly blank, overhung face on the left side of the wall. The topout is about 3-4 feet right of the crack that Hepatitis tops out on.

content.description: The crux is the final move to the jug.  You need good balance to pull yourself to the half moon.  Very fun route, not especially hard but an interesting balance problem none the less.
content.protection: A pad below the final move. While traversing, you have good feet and are pretty close to the ground, except for the last reach.
content.location: The start is located about 6-7 feet left, if facing Crackerjack Dyno. The start is two small, 1 finger chips used for balance at the very end of the boulder. Traverse  along the large walkway using small chips for balance until you reach a small sharp half moon crimp facing you. Use that and a high chip to pull yourself up to grab a large jug at the top of the boulder. Top out here.

content.description: Start at the right end of the angling crack, at the starting holds for Hepatitis. Traverse the crack up and left to the wide, vertical crack. Continue left across the crack, with your feet on the slabby ramp and your hands on crimpy cobbles around the lip. Stop at the end or traverse back the way you can.This is lowball and convenient for laps and is a good for a pump at the end of the day.
content.location: As the name suggests, this traverses the left end of the Pusherman Wall, extending from the start of Hepatitis left to the end of the wall.

content.description: Just Say No ascends the obvious dirty offwidth on Pusherman Wall. It is a fun climb to practice wide moves on.
content.protection: Use wide gear or a toprope.
content.location: It is the dirty offwidth in the middle of the wall.

content.description: Stand start on good crimps around chest height. Climb up on positive edges with some jugs. The upper portion is easy but highball.
content.location: Start ~3 yards left of the arete (EZ Wider) at the right end of the Pusherman Wall, just left of the blank section.

content.description:
This route is on the face about 4-5 feet left of "The Bone", which is the crack route to the right of Pusherman Wall. The crack is off. Step up onto some blocks, climb up the chunky face to reach an undercling about 2 feet across. From there, it's pretty easy climbing up to a horizontal crack a couple feet below the top. 

  We found this route in Boston Rocks, 2nd edition, p. 103. There is not much beta there, just a rough drawing.
content.protection: Top rope. We used the anchor that we'd set up for "The Bones". Just beware the pendulum as you go higher. Use long slings, the trees are 20 feet or so back.
content.location:
The route is about 4-5 feet left of the crack route, "The Bone". The bottom is a cluster of blocks where the face is broken up. Currently they are covered in paint, but it's not slippery and doesn't hinder climbing. Start on the blocks, and aim for the broad undercling, straight up. 

  You can top out or lower down.

content.description:
This is a classic climb done by Henry Barber when sticky rubber and crash pads did not exist. It was given a wide range 5.12 grade.  

  Start on crimps at chest height. Make a couple hard deadpoints up and right along a seam to a jug. Then make a couple big moves on big holds to gain the slab topout.
content.location: This is on the left side of the Pusherman's Wall where it's steep.

content.description: This is a sustained face climb. The sit start adds length, not really difficulty.
content.location: Find the start to Hepatitis, and head straight up instead of traversing.

content.description: Sit start at the bottom of the horizontal crack, and then traverse from right to left until you meet up with EZ Wider to top out.
content.location: Start about 10 feet to the right of EZ Wider (the big, blunt arête at the right end of Pusherman Wall) at the rightmost end of the crack, then traverse left to the arête, and top out with EZ Wider.

content.description: Sit start at the bottom of the horizontal crack, and then climb straight up on crimps.
content.location: Start about 10 feet to the right of EZ Wider (the big, blunt arête at the right end of Pusherman Wall) at the rightmost end of the crack, then climb straight up.

content.description: Climb up the arete on big holds. The sit start is an option.
content.location: This ascends the obvious arete forming the right end of the Pusherman Wall.

content.description: Crouch start on the chalked up jug on the lower seam. Scrunch your feet up, and dyno to the juggy crack well above. Traverse the crack left to the topout. This is a really fun dyno problem that is a must-do when at the Temple Area.
content.protection: A pad, a spotter is not really necessary - it has an almost perfect landing.
content.location: Below the start of Hepatitus, there is a left-trending, juggy crack. As the crack moves diagonally up and left, there is a seam that goes dead left, connecting the juggy crack to a wider crack out left. Smack in the middle of the seam, there is a chalked up jug. This is the start.

content.description: Corgi Magic is a run-and-jump problem to the right of Hepatitis aka Hepatitus, where the wall has been tagged with "Game" in red graffiti. About 3 feet off the ground is a slopey knob. Kick off this, and fire straight up to the jug at about 10 feet. Do the same finish as Hepatitis aka Hepatitus.
content.protection: A couple of pads. Also, try to avoid missing the foothold and smashing face-first into the wall.

content.description:
Sit start at the crack at the base of Hepatitis and Goofball but a foot or two to the left. Move up left to a decent crimp. Tricky footwork will gain you a "tongue" hold and a shallow pocket where a pebble used to be. Gain the crazy looking hold above to set up for the topout.

 The story is that this was a 5.11 when the pebble was still there. Now that it is gone, it is much more challenging.
content.location: This is just to the left of the Hepatitis/Goofball.

content.description:
Start about 5 feet right of Overdose, and climb straight up.

 Note: despite the YDS rating from ages ago, this is really a boulder problem.
content.location: It is in the middle of Pusherman Wall between Overdose and It's the Real Thing. See the picture on the Pusherman Wall page.

content.description: Stand start, and climb straight up on positive edges and jugs. This is a highball but is secure.
content.location: It is a couple yards right of The Bone and 3-4 feet left of Joint Distribution.

content.description: If you face Pusherman Wall, "The Bone" is the obvious crack furthest to the right of the wall. Boston Rocks 2nd edition (p. 103) shows the route going up just to the right of the crack. I'm not sure if the intention is to use the crack for your hands and put your feet right of it, or if you are free to use the crack for your feet. We did it both ways. There are lots of good holds for hands and feet.
content.protection: Top rope. Possibly it can be led; I wouldn't try it because I don't trust puddingstone not to break. There are some large trees about 15-20 feet back from the top of this route which can be used for anchors. Bring long slings or static line.
content.location:
The route is straightforward, going up the crack on the right side of Pusherman Wall. The crack wanders a little. It veers up to the right a couple of feet at the bottom, and then trends a little right and then up. 

  Just follow the crack up to your anchors. The crack ends shortly before the top of the climb. It's easy to top out here, or lower down if you prefer. 

  Note there is some paint at the bottom of the climb. It looks like it was done to cover up graffiti. The paint is not slippery and doesn't cause any problems when climbing.

content.description:
I believe this route is on the Pusherman's Wall and is on the way on the side before the boulder levels off and becomes a slab. It is a short route about 4-5 moves to the topout. 

  Start right and climb out left and move up to a nice sidepull. Watch out not to barndoor and flag your foot! I did not see this route labeled anywhere, and it is short but fun! Take a turn on it!

This is fun crag with interesting problems on fun rock. This crag, while short, is quite wide. It would provide a very challenging girdle traverse for someone. At times, you can lose the sense that you are in a metropolitan area while climbing here. Technique wins over brute strength at this crag.Apparently, to the left of Pusherman Wall is The Cave, a fun 7 foot cave.L->R:A. Left End Traverse, 7 or V0.B. Bannana Pancakes (aka Upper?), 8 or V0-V1, 10'.C. Downer, 1D. Bennie, 9E. Skin Pop, 11Below F. Crackerjack Dyno, V2.F. Cold Turkey, 11 or V5, 12', TR or boulder.G1. Goofball, 12 or V3 or V4, 15', TR or boulder.G2. Hepatitus, 12 or V5, 15', TR or boulder.H. The Snort, 9- or V0, 15', TR or boulder.I. Yes!, 3, 20', TR.J. Just Say No, 5 or 6, 15', TR or boulder.K. THC, 4, 15', TR or boulder.L. Overdose, 3, 1p, 15', TR or boulder.M. Coke, 4, 1p, 15', TR or boulder.N. It's the Real Thing, 4, 20', TR.O. The Bone, 2, 20', TR or gear?P. Vegigatabla, 4 or V0-, 20', TR or boulder.Q. Brain Burners, 6 or V0, 20', TR or boulder.R. Joint Distributions, 7+ or V1, 20', TR or boulder.S. EZ Wider, 4 or V0, 20', TR or boulder.T? EZ Wider Slab, V1.U? Doc, 4V? Lily, 7W? Dillon, 5
